content.text: What is HTML5?

HTML5 is the latest version of HTML (HyperText Markup Language), the standard language for creating web pages. Think of HTML as the skeleton of a webpage - it defines the structure and content. HTML5 introduced many new features that make websites more interactive, accessible, and search-engine friendly.

items: Semantic Elements: Tags that describe their meaning (like <header>, <nav>, <main>)
Better Accessibility: Screen readers can better understand page structure
SEO Benefits: Search engines better understand your content organization
New Input Types: Email, date, color pickers built into browsers
Multimedia Support: Native video and audio elements without plugins
Offline Capabilities: Can work without internet connection
Mobile Optimization: Better support for responsive design

Semantic HTML5 Elements Explained

Semantic elements are like labeled boxes - they tell both browsers and developers what type of content is inside. Instead of using generic <div> tags everywhere, semantic elements make your code more meaningful and accessible.

items: <header>: Like a book cover - contains site logo, main navigation, introductory content
<nav>: The table of contents - contains navigation links to other pages or sections
<main>: The main story - contains the primary content of the page (only one per page)
<section>: Like book chapters - groups related content together, usually with a heading
<article>: Standalone content that makes sense on its own (blog posts, news articles, comments)
<aside>: Sidebar content - related but not essential (ads, related links, author bio)
<footer>: Like a book's back cover - contains copyright, contact info, additional links
<figure> & <figcaption>: For images with captions, like photos in a magazine
<details> & <summary>: Creates expandable content (FAQ sections, show/hide content)
<time>: Marks dates and times so browsers and search engines understand them better

Modern Form Elements & Validation

HTML5 forms are much more powerful than old HTML forms. They include built-in validation (no JavaScript needed!), better input types, and improved accessibility. Think of forms as conversations with your users - you want to make them as easy and clear as possible.

<form method="POST" novalidate> <!-- novalidate lets us customize error messages -->
  <fieldset> <!-- Groups related form fields together -->
    <legend>Personal Information</legend> <!-- Title for the group -->
    
    <!-- Email input with built-in validation -->
    <label for="email">Email Address *</label>
    <input type="email" id="email" name="email" 
           required <!-- Browser won't submit without this -->
           autocomplete="email" <!-- Helps browsers auto-fill -->
           aria-describedby="email-help" <!-- Links to help text -->
           placeholder="your@email.com">
    <small id="email-help">We'll never share your email with anyone</small>
    
    <!-- Password with minimum length -->
    <label for="password">Password *</label>
    <input type="password" id="password" name="password" 
           required 
           minlength="8" <!-- Must be at least 8 characters -->
           autocomplete="new-password"
           aria-describedby="password-help">
    <small id="password-help">Must be at least 8 characters long</small>
    
    <!-- Date input (shows date picker) -->
    <label for="birthdate">Birth Date</label>
    <input type="date" id="birthdate" name="birthdate"
           min="1900-01-01" max="2024-12-31">
    
    <!-- Number input with range -->
    <label for="age">Age</label>
    <input type="number" id="age" name="age" 
           min="13" max="120" step="1">
    
    <!-- Radio buttons for single choice -->
    <fieldset>
      <legend>Preferred Contact Method</legend>
      <label><input type="radio" name="contact" value="email" checked> Email</label>
      <label><input type="radio" name="contact" value="phone"> Phone</label>
      <label><input type="radio" name="contact" value="text"> Text Message</label>
    </fieldset>
    
    <!-- Checkboxes for multiple choices -->
    <fieldset>
      <legend>Interests (select all that apply)</legend>
      <label><input type="checkbox" name="interests" value="web-dev"> Web Development</label>
      <label><input type="checkbox" name="interests" value="design"> Design</label>
      <label><input type="checkbox" name="interests" value="mobile"> Mobile Apps</label>
    </fieldset>
    
    <!-- Dropdown selection -->
    <label for="experience">Experience Level</label>
    <select id="experience" name="experience" required>
      <option value="">Please select...</option>
      <option value="beginner">Beginner (0-1 years)</option>
      <option value="intermediate">Intermediate (2-5 years)</option>
      <option value="advanced">Advanced (5+ years)</option>
    </select>
    
    <!-- Large text input -->
    <label for="message">Additional Comments</label>
    <textarea id="message" name="message" 
              rows="4" cols="50"
              placeholder="Tell us more about yourself..."></textarea>
  </fieldset>
  
  <button type="submit">Create Account</button>
  <button type="reset">Clear Form</button>
</form>
Web Accessibility & ARIA - Making Web for Everyone

Web accessibility means making your website usable by everyone, including people with disabilities. ARIA (Accessible Rich Internet Applications) attributes provide extra information for screen readers and other assistive technologies. Think of ARIA as adding helpful descriptions for people who can't see your interface.

What is CSS?

CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) is what makes websites look beautiful. If HTML is the skeleton of a webpage, CSS is the skin, clothes, and makeup. It controls colors, fonts, layouts, animations, and how your website responds to different screen sizes. Modern CSS is incredibly powerful and can create stunning visual effects.
CSS Custom Properties (Variables) - Your Design System

CSS custom properties (also called CSS variables) are like having a color palette and style guide that you can change instantly across your entire website. Instead of repeating the same colors and sizes everywhere, you define them once and reuse them. This makes maintaining and updating your design much easier.
Modern CSS Selectors (2024) - Powerful Selection Tools

Modern CSS selectors are like super-powered search tools that let you target exactly the elements you want to style. These new selectors make your CSS more efficient and reduce the need for extra HTML classes.
CSS Logical Properties - International-Friendly CSS

Logical properties adapt automatically to different writing directions (left-to-right vs right-to-left languages like Arabic or Hebrew). Instead of thinking about physical directions (left/right), think about logical directions (start/end). This makes your website work better internationally.
Flexbox for One-Dimensional Layouts
Flexbox is perfect for distributing space and aligning items in one dimension (either row or column).
CSS Grid for Two-Dimensional Layouts
CSS Grid excels at creating complex two-dimensional layouts with precise control over rows and columns.

CSS Loading Optimization
Optimize CSS delivery to improve page load performance and user experience.

<!-- Critical CSS inline -->
<style>
  /* Critical above-the-fold styles */
  body { font-family: system-ui, sans-serif; }
  .header { background: #fff; padding: 1rem; }
</style>

<!-- Non-critical CSS with preload -->
<link rel="preload" href="styles.css" as="style" onload="this.onload=null;this.rel='stylesheet'">
<noscript><link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css"></noscript>

<!-- Font loading optimization -->
<link rel="preconnect" href="https://fonts.googleapis.com">
<link rel="preconnect" href="https://fonts.gstatic.com" crossorigin>
<link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Inter:wght@400;600&display=swap" rel="stylesheet">

<!-- Resource hints -->
<link rel="dns-prefetch" href="//example.com">
<link rel="preconnect" href="https://api.example.com">
CSS Performance Best Practices

items: Use efficient selectors: avoid universal (*) and complex descendant selectors
Minimize reflows and repaints: use transform and opacity for animations
Optimize font loading: use font-display: swap for web fonts
Use CSS containment: contain: layout style paint for isolated components
Minimize CSS bundle size: remove unused CSS, use CSS purging tools
Use CSS custom properties for dynamic styling instead of JavaScript
Optimize images: use modern formats (WebP, AVIF), responsive images
Use CSS Grid and Flexbox instead of floats and positioning

testQuestions.question: What is the purpose of the <!DOCTYPE html> declaration?
options: It defines the HTML version and tells the browser to use HTML5 parsing rules
It's optional and doesn't affect how the page renders
testQuestions.explanation: The DOCTYPE declaration is an instruction to the browser about which version of HTML the page is written in. <!DOCTYPE html> tells the browser to use HTML5 parsing rules and prevents quirks mode.

testQuestions.question: Which HTML5 semantic element should contain the main content of a page?
testQuestions.explanation: The <main> element represents the main content of the page. There should only be one <main> element per page, and it helps screen readers and other assistive technologies navigate directly to the primary content.

testQuestions.question: What is the difference between <section> and <article> elements?
options: <section> groups thematic content, <article> represents standalone content
<article> is for news only, <section> is for everything else
testQuestions.explanation: <section> represents a thematic grouping of content with a heading, while <article> represents standalone, self-contained content that could be distributed independently (like blog posts, news articles).

testQuestions.question: What does the 'aria-live' attribute do?
options: Announces dynamic content changes to screen readers
testQuestions.explanation: The aria-live attribute creates a 'live region' that announces dynamic content changes to screen readers. 'polite' waits for the user to finish, while 'assertive' interrupts immediately.

testQuestions.question: What is the advantage of using CSS custom properties (variables)?
options: They enable dynamic styling, better maintainability, and cascade
They are required for modern browsers
They replace all other CSS features
testQuestions.explanation: CSS custom properties cascade like regular CSS properties, can be manipulated with JavaScript, enable theme switching, and make CSS more maintainable by centralizing values.

testQuestions.question: What does the CSS :has() pseudo-class do?
options: Selects elements that have a specific class
Selects parent elements based on their children
Checks if an element has content
testQuestions.explanation: The :has() pseudo-class is a 'parent selector' that selects elements based on what they contain. For example, .form-field:has(:invalid) selects form fields that contain invalid inputs.

testQuestions.question: What are CSS logical properties?
options: Properties that adapt to writing modes and text direction
testQuestions.explanation: CSS logical properties like padding-inline and margin-block adapt to different writing modes and text directions, making CSS more internationalization-friendly than physical properties like left/right.

testQuestions.question: When should you use Flexbox vs CSS Grid?
options: Always use Grid, Flexbox is outdated
Flexbox for one-dimensional layouts, Grid for two-dimensional layouts
Grid for mobile, Flexbox for desktop
testQuestions.explanation: Use Flexbox for one-dimensional layouts (distributing items in a row or column) and CSS Grid for two-dimensional layouts (controlling both rows and columns simultaneously).

testQuestions.question: What is the 'gap' property used for?
options: Adding space between flex or grid items
testQuestions.explanation: The gap property adds space between items in flexbox and grid containers. It's the modern way to add spacing without using margins that can cause layout issues.

testQuestions.question: What does 'aspect-ratio: 16 / 9' do?
options: Maintains a 16:9 width-to-height ratio regardless of content
Divides the element into 16 columns and 9 rows
testQuestions.explanation: The aspect-ratio property maintains a specific width-to-height ratio. aspect-ratio: 16 / 9 ensures the element maintains a 16:9 ratio, useful for responsive videos and images.

testQuestions.question: What is mobile-first responsive design?
options: Starting with mobile styles and progressively enhancing for larger screens
testQuestions.explanation: Mobile-first design starts with mobile styles as the base and uses min-width media queries to progressively enhance for larger screens, resulting in better performance and user experience.

testQuestions.question: What does 'clamp(1rem, 4vw, 3rem)' do?
options: Sets a fixed font size of 1rem
Creates a responsive font size between 1rem and 3rem based on viewport width
Adds animation to font size changes
Sets different font sizes for different devices
testQuestions.explanation: clamp() sets a responsive value with a minimum (1rem), preferred (4vw), and maximum (3rem). The font size scales with the viewport but never goes below 1rem or above 3rem.

testQuestions.question: What does '@media (prefers-reduced-motion: reduce)' detect?
options: User preference to minimize animations for accessibility
testQuestions.explanation: This media query detects when users have enabled 'reduce motion' in their system settings, often for vestibular disorders or motion sensitivity. It's important for accessibility.

testQuestions.question: What is CSS nesting?
options: Putting CSS files inside other files
Writing CSS selectors inside other selectors, like in Sass
testQuestions.explanation: CSS nesting allows you to write CSS selectors inside other selectors, similar to Sass/SCSS. This is now natively supported in modern browsers without preprocessing.

testQuestions.question: What does 'color-mix(in srgb, blue 70%, white)' do?
options: Creates a gradient from blue to white
Mixes 70% blue with 30% white to create a new color
Sets blue as primary and white as secondary color
testQuestions.explanation: color-mix() is a modern CSS function that blends two colors. This example mixes 70% blue with 30% white in the sRGB color space to create a light blue color.

testQuestions.question: What are CSS layers (@layer) used for?
options: Controlling the cascade and specificity order
testQuestions.explanation: CSS layers provide explicit control over the cascade. Styles in later layers override earlier layers regardless of specificity, making CSS architecture more predictable.

testQuestions.question: What does 'container-type: inline-size' enable?
options: Container queries based on the container's width
testQuestions.explanation: Container queries allow styling based on a container's size rather than the viewport. 'inline-size' enables queries based on the container's width (inline dimension).

testQuestions.question: Why should you use 'transform' instead of changing 'left/top' for animations?
options: Transform is GPU-accelerated and doesn't trigger layout recalculation
testQuestions.explanation: Transform operations are GPU-accelerated and don't trigger layout recalculation (reflow), making animations much smoother and more performant than changing layout properties like left/top.

testQuestions.question: What does 'font-display: swap' do?
options: Shows fallback font immediately while web font loads
Switches fonts based on screen size
testQuestions.explanation: font-display: swap shows the fallback font immediately and swaps to the web font when it loads, preventing invisible text during font load (FOIT - Flash of Invisible Text).

testQuestions.question: What is the purpose of 'content-visibility: auto'?
options: Optimizes rendering by skipping off-screen content
Makes content visible to screen readers
testQuestions.explanation: content-visibility: auto is a performance optimization that allows the browser to skip rendering work for off-screen content, improving page load and scroll performance.

testQuestions.question: What does the 'inert' attribute do in HTML?
options: Makes elements non-interactive and hidden from assistive technology
testQuestions.explanation: The inert attribute makes an element and its descendants non-interactive (can't be focused, clicked) and hidden from assistive technology, useful for modal overlays.

testQuestions.question: What is the difference between 'grid-template-columns: repeat(auto-fit, minmax(300px, 1fr))' and 'repeat(auto-fill, minmax(300px, 1fr))'?
options: auto-fit collapses empty columns, auto-fill maintains them
testQuestions.explanation: auto-fit collapses empty grid tracks and stretches remaining items to fill the container, while auto-fill maintains empty tracks, keeping items at their minimum size.

testQuestions.question: What does 'scroll-behavior: smooth' do?
options: Adds smooth scrolling animation when jumping to anchor links
testQuestions.explanation: scroll-behavior: smooth adds smooth scrolling animation when navigating to anchor links or using scrollIntoView(), improving user experience during page navigation.

testQuestions.question: What is the purpose of the 'loading="lazy"' attribute on images?
options: Defers image loading until they're near the viewport
testQuestions.explanation: loading="lazy" implements native lazy loading, deferring image loading until they're about to enter the viewport, improving initial page load performance.

testQuestions.question: What does ':focus-visible' target that ':focus' doesn't?
options: Only elements focused via keyboard navigation
testQuestions.explanation: :focus-visible only applies focus styles when the browser determines focus should be visible (typically keyboard navigation), avoiding unwanted focus rings on mouse clicks.
